greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = phi(n)^2.
comment: Number of maps of the form j |--> m*j + d with gcd(m, n) = 1 and gcd(d, n) = 1 from [1, 2, ..., n] to itself. - _Joerg Arndt_, Aug 29 2014
Equals the Mobius transform (A054525) of A029939. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Aug 20 2008
a(n) is the number of solutions to gcd(xy, n) = 1 with x, y in [0, n-1].

Let Z_n be the ring of integers modulo n, then a(n) is the number of invertible elements in the ring Z_n[x]/(x^2 - x) (or equivalently, Z_n[x]/(x^2 + x)) with discriminant d = 1 (that is, a(n) is the size of the group G(n) = (Z_n[x]/(x^2 - x))*). Actually, G(n) is isomorphic to (Z_n)* X (Z_n)*. (End)
link: Jens Kruse Andersen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
N. J. A. Sloane, Families of Essentially Identical Sequences, Mar 24 2021 (Includes this sequence)
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^e) = (p-1)^2*p^(2e-2), e >= 1. Dirichlet g.f. zeta(s-2)*Product_{primes p} (1 - 2/p^(s-1) + 1/p^s). - _R. J. Mathar_, Apr 04 2011
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_, Jan 15 2007
